sen.j: 大名行列（だいみょうぎょうれつ）は、大名が公用のために随員を引き連れて外出する際に取る行列のこと。
sen.e: Daimyo-gyoretsu refers to procession that was formed when daimyo went out along with attendants for public purpose.

sen.cmt: 用語共有の説明を追加しました。

sen.j: 参勤交代における江戸と領地との往来が典型的な形態である。
sen.e: The typical form was traffic between Edo and territory in Sankinkotai (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo).

sen.j: 大名行列は本来、戦時の行軍に準じた臨戦的・軍事的な移動形態（帯刀する刀の長さも通常の長さより大きなものでもよいなど）であったが、江戸時代の太平が続くと次第に大名の権威と格式を誇示するための政治的なものに変容した。
sen.e: Daimyo-gyoretsu initially referred to a military form of traffic based on march in war time (sword taken along could be longer than ordinary one), but as peace in Edo lasted long, it gradually changed to a political thing to show off their authority and social status.
sen.cmt: 「臨戦的」は、対応する英語の形容詞が見つからない上、「軍事的」と同等の意味ととらえ、英訳しませんでした。
sen.e: Daimyo-gyoretsu initially referred to a form of military traffic preparing for battles which was based on a march in war time (for example, longer swords than ordinary one were allowed to carry), but as peace in Edo lasted long, it gradually changed to a political thing to show off their authority and social status.

sen.j: 随員には騎馬・徒歩の武士の他、火縄銃、弓 (武器)などの足軽や道具箱や槍持ちなどの中間（人足）、草履取や医師などの大名身辺に仕える者たちが連なる。
sen.e: Attendants were consisted of people served daimyo such as warriors, horse-riding or on foot, ashigaru (common foot soldier) carrying matchlock gun or bow (arm), chugen (a rank below common soldier) (or ninsoku 〔coolie〕) carrying tool box or spear, zoritori (sandal bearer, equivalent to a batman) and doctors.

sen.j: 参勤交代などの江戸幕府の公用のために行う大名行列は幕府によって人数が定められており、1万石の小大名でも50人から100人を引き連れることを義務付けられ、102万石の加賀藩では最盛期に4,000人に及んだ。
sen.e: Daimyo-gyoretsu which was carried on for public purpose of Edo bakufu such as Sankinkotai had a fixed number of attendants, so even small feudal lords with only ten thousands Goku crop yields were obligated to take fifty to one hundred attendants, and the number of Kaga domain with one million twenty thousands Goku crop yields reached four thousands attendants at its peak.

sen.j: これは、大名行列のために出費を強いることで諸大名が経済的実力を持つことを抑制しようとする政治的意図による。
sen.e: This is because of political intention to restrain territorial lords' financial power by forcing them to make a lot of expense for daimyo-gyoretsu.

sen.j: しかし幕末にはこの負担が多くの大名の財政を圧迫し、むしろ幕府への不満を増大させ、討幕運動の遠因となった。
sen.e: However, in the end of Bakufu, the load put a pressure to financial affairs of many daimyo, and it rather increased their dissatisfaction with Bakufu, which became an underlying cause of anti-shogunate movement.

sen.e: However, toward the end of the Edo period, this obligation put a strain on the finances of many daimyo, increasing their dissatisfaction with the bakufu and becoming an underlying cause of the anti-shogunate movement.

sen.j: 時代劇等では、大名行列が往来を通り過ぎるときには必ず先導の旗持ちの「下にー、下にー」との声にあわせ百姓、商人などは脇により平伏しているシーンが登場するが、実際にはこの掛け声を使えるのは徳川御三家（なお水戸藩は例外で参勤交代はなかった）だけで、ほかの大名家は「よけろ～、よけろ～」という掛け声を用い、脇に避けるだけでよかった。
sen.e: In jidaigeki (historical play), there sometimes is a scene that a standard-bearer calls out "Shitani, Shitani" when daimyo-gyoretsu goes through a street, letting peasants and merchants prostrate at the side of the street, but actually this call-out could have been used by only Tokugawa gosanke (three privileged branches of Tokugawa family) (Mito domain was exceptionally having no Sankinkotai), and other daimyo families instead used "Yokero, Yokero", just letting people step aside.
sen.cmt: 「下にー、下にー」と「よけろ～、よけろ～」はローマ字表記しました。

sen.j: 大名行列の前を横切ったり、列を乱す様な行為は無礼な行いとされ、生麦事件の例を挙げるまでもなくその場で『切捨御免』にする事も許されていたが、特例として出産の取上げに向かっている産婆（現在の助産師）は、行列の前を横切る事を許されていた。
sen.e: Crossing in front of daimyo-gyoretsu and disordering the procession were regarded as a rude behavior, so if someone did, he could be killed on the spot according to kirisute gomen (the privilege granted to samurai warriors), without referring to an exemple of Namamugi Incident here, but as a special case, a midwife heading to assist childbirth was allowed to cross in front of procession.
sen.cmt: （現在の助産師）については、その前の「産婆」の英訳ですでに意味が通じているので、ここでは英訳しませんでした。
sen.e: Crossing in front of daimyo-gyoretsu and disordering the procession were regarded as a rude behavior, those who did it could be killed on the spot according to kirisute gomen (the privilege granted to samurai warriors), without referring to the case of Namamugi Incident, but as a special case, midwives heading to assist childbirth were allowed to cross in front of procession.
sen.cmt: 原文に沿って表現をシンプル化、修正しました。
sen.e: Crossing in front of the daimyo-gyoretsu and thereby disrupting the procession was regarded as rude behavior; in fact, those who did so could be killed on the spot (as was the case in a prime example of which was the case in the Namamugi Incident) in accordance with kirisute gomen (the privilege granted to samurai warriors), but as a special exception, midwives heading to assist childbirth were allowed to cross in front of the procession.
